docs.text: HoTT Book formalisations in Rzk ¶ This project contains formalisations that follow the HoTT Book . How to check ¶ From the root of the project's repository, run: rzk typecheck src/**/*.rzk.md

docs.text: 1.4 Dependent function types ( \(\Pi\) -types) ¶ This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1 A polymorphic function is one which takes a type as one of its arguments, and then acts on elements of that type (or of other types constructed from it). An example is the polymorphic identity function: #define id ( A : U) : A → A := \ x → x Another, less trivial, example of a polymorphic function is the "swap" operation that switches the order of the arguments of a (curried) two-argument function: #define swap ( A B C : U) : (A → B → C) → (B → A → C) := \ f y x → f x y
docs.title: 1.4 Dependent function types

docs.text: This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1 A polymorphic function is one which takes a type as one of its arguments, and then acts on elements of that type (or of other types constructed from it). An example is the polymorphic identity function: #define id ( A : U) : A → A := \ x → x Another, less trivial, example of a polymorphic function is the "swap" operation that switches the order of the arguments of a (curried) two-argument function: #define swap ( A B C : U) : (A → B → C) → (B → A → C) := \ f y x → f x y
docs.title: 1.4 Dependent function types (\(\Pi\)-types)

docs.text: 1.5 Product types ¶ This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1 Rzk has built-in support for dependent pairs, so we define product types here in terms of those. #define prod ( A B : U) : U := Σ ( _ : A), B To construct a pair, we can now simply use tuple syntax for \(\Sigma\) -types: (a, b) . To use a pair, we can use pattern matching or introduce projections: #define pr₁ ( A B : U) : prod A B → A := \ (a, _b) → a #define pr₂ ( A B : U) : prod A B → B := \ (_a, b) → b The recursor for product types can be defined as follows: #define prod-rec ( A B : U) : ( C : U) → (A → B → C) → prod A B → C := \ C f (a, b) → f a b Then instead of defining functions such as pr1 and pr2 directly by a defining equation, we could define #define pr₁-via-rec ( A B : U) : prod A B → A := prod-rec A B A ( \ a _b → a) #define pr₂-via-rec ( A B : U) : prod A B → B := prod-rec A B B ( \ _a b → b) To be able to define dependent functions over the product type, we have to generalize the recursor: #define prod-ind ( A B : U) : ( C : prod A B → U) → ( (x : A) → ( y : B) → C (x, y)) → ( x : prod A B) → C x := \ C f (x, y) → f x y For example, in this way we can prove the propositional uniqueness principle, which says that every element of A × B is equal to a pair. Specifically, we can construct a function #define prod-uniq ( A B : U) : ( x : prod A B) → (pr₁ A B x, pr₂ A B x) =_{prod A B} x := \ (a, b) → refl _{(a, b)} Unit type ¶ Rzk has a built-in Unit type which behaves slightly differently from the unit type in the HoTT Book. In particular, in Rzk, uniqueness principle for the unit type is built in, making some proofs easier than in the book. Still, following the book, here is the recursor for the unit type: #define Unit-rec : ( C : U) → C → Unit → C := \ _C c _unit → c And, similarly, the induction principle for the unit type: #define Unit-ind : ( C : Unit → U) → C unit → ( x : Unit) → C x := \ _C c unit → c Induction enables us to prove the propositional uniqueness principle for Unit , which asserts that its only inhabitant is unit : #define Unit-uniq : ( x : Unit) → x = unit := Unit-ind ( \ x → x = unit ) refl _{ unit } As mentioned above, this uniqueness principle is built into Rzk (making any value of type Unit definitionally equal to unit ), allowing to use refl immediately: #define Unit-uniq' : ( x : Unit) → x = unit := \ _ → refl
docs.title: 1.5 Product types

docs.text: This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1 Rzk has built-in support for dependent pairs, so we define product types here in terms of those. #define prod ( A B : U) : U := Σ ( _ : A), B To construct a pair, we can now simply use tuple syntax for \(\Sigma\) -types: (a, b) . To use a pair, we can use pattern matching or introduce projections: #define pr₁ ( A B : U) : prod A B → A := \ (a, _b) → a #define pr₂ ( A B : U) : prod A B → B := \ (_a, b) → b The recursor for product types can be defined as follows: #define prod-rec ( A B : U) : ( C : U) → (A → B → C) → prod A B → C := \ C f (a, b) → f a b Then instead of defining functions such as pr1 and pr2 directly by a defining equation, we could define #define pr₁-via-rec ( A B : U) : prod A B → A := prod-rec A B A ( \ a _b → a) #define pr₂-via-rec ( A B : U) : prod A B → B := prod-rec A B B ( \ _a b → b) To be able to define dependent functions over the product type, we have to generalize the recursor: #define prod-ind ( A B : U) : ( C : prod A B → U) → ( (x : A) → ( y : B) → C (x, y)) → ( x : prod A B) → C x := \ C f (x, y) → f x y For example, in this way we can prove the propositional uniqueness principle, which says that every element of A × B is equal to a pair. Specifically, we can construct a function #define prod-uniq ( A B : U) : ( x : prod A B) → (pr₁ A B x, pr₂ A B x) =_{prod A B} x := \ (a, b) → refl _{(a, b)}
docs.title: 1.5 Product types

docs.text: Rzk has a built-in Unit type which behaves slightly differently from the unit type in the HoTT Book. In particular, in Rzk, uniqueness principle for the unit type is built in, making some proofs easier than in the book. Still, following the book, here is the recursor for the unit type: #define Unit-rec : ( C : U) → C → Unit → C := \ _C c _unit → c And, similarly, the induction principle for the unit type: #define Unit-ind : ( C : Unit → U) → C unit → ( x : Unit) → C x := \ _C c unit → c Induction enables us to prove the propositional uniqueness principle for Unit , which asserts that its only inhabitant is unit : #define Unit-uniq : ( x : Unit) → x = unit := Unit-ind ( \ x → x = unit ) refl _{ unit } As mentioned above, this uniqueness principle is built into Rzk (making any value of type Unit definitionally equal to unit ), allowing to use refl immediately: #define Unit-uniq' : ( x : Unit) → x = unit := \ _ → refl
docs.title: Unit type

docs.text: 1.6 Dependent pair types ¶ This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1 TODO #def pr₁-sigma ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) : ( Sigma (x : A), (B x)) -> A := \ p -> first p #def pr₂-sigma ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) : ( p : Sigma ( x : A), (B x)) -> (B ( first p)) := \ p -> second p Recursor for sigma types. They are called like this: \[ \mathsf{rec}_{\Sigma_{x : A}B(x)} ((C: U), (g: (x : A) \rightarrow B (x) \rightarrow C), (p: \Sigma_{x : A} B(x))) \] #def rec-sigma ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( C : U) : ( g : ( x : A) -> B x -> C) -> ( p : Sigma ( x : A), (B x)) -> C := \ g (a, b) -> g a b #def ind-sigma ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( C : ( Sigma (x : A), (B x)) -> U) : ( g : ( x : A) -> ( y : B x) -> C (x, y)) -> ( p : Sigma ( x : A), (B x)) -> C p := \ g (a, b) -> g a b
docs.title: 1.6 Dependent pair types

docs.text: This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1 TODO #def pr₁-sigma ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) : ( Sigma (x : A), (B x)) -> A := \ p -> first p #def pr₂-sigma ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) : ( p : Sigma ( x : A), (B x)) -> (B ( first p)) := \ p -> second p Recursor for sigma types. They are called like this: \[ \mathsf{rec}_{\Sigma_{x : A}B(x)} ((C: U), (g: (x : A) \rightarrow B (x) \rightarrow C), (p: \Sigma_{x : A} B(x))) \] #def rec-sigma ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( C : U) : ( g : ( x : A) -> B x -> C) -> ( p : Sigma ( x : A), (B x)) -> C := \ g (a, b) -> g a b #def ind-sigma ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( C : ( Sigma (x : A), (B x)) -> U) : ( g : ( x : A) -> ( y : B x) -> C (x, y)) -> ( p : Sigma ( x : A), (B x)) -> C p := \ g (a, b) -> g a b
docs.title: 1.6 Dependent pair types

docs.text: Exercises for Section 1 ¶ Exercise 1.1 ¶ Given functions \(f : A \to B\) and \(g : B \to C\) , define their composite \(g \circ f : A \to C\) . Show that we have \(h \circ (g \circ f) \equiv (h \circ g) \circ f\) . Go to solution Exercise 1.2 ¶ Derive the recursion principle for products \(rec_{A \times B}\) using only the projections, and verify that the definitional equalities are valid. Do the same for \(\Sigma\) -types. Go to solution Exercise 1.3 ¶ Derive the induction principle for products \(ind_{A \times B}\) , using only the projections and the propositional uniqueness principle \(uniq_{A \times B}\) . Verify that the definitional equalities are valid. Generalize \(uniq_{A \times B}\) to \(\Sigma\) -types, and do the same for \(\Sigma\) -types. (This requires concepts from Chapter 2.) Go to solution Exercise 1.4 ¶ Warning Description is missing. Go to solution Exercise 1.5 ¶ Warning Description is missing. Go to solution Exercise 1.6 ¶ Warning Description is missing. docs.text: Solution to exercise 1.1 ¶ This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1 Problem statement ¶ Given functions \(f : A \to B\) and \(g : B \to C\) , define their composite \(g \circ f : A \to C\) . Show that we have \(h \circ (g \circ f) \equiv (h \circ g) \circ f\) . Solution ¶ #define compose ( A B C : U) ( g : B → C) ( f : A → B) : A → C := \ x → g (f x) Associativity is automatic (by refl ): #def compose_associativity ( A B C D : U) ( f : A -> B) ( g : B -> C) ( h : C -> D) : compose A C D h (compose A B C g f) = compose A B D (compose B C D h g) f := refl An explicit proof (not checked by rzk ): -- compose A C D h (compose A B C g f) -- = \ x → h ((compose A B C g f) x) (unfolding compose) -- = \ x → h ((\ x2 → g (f x2)) x) (unfolding compose) -- = \ x → h (g (f x)) (beta) -- = \ x → (\ x2 → h (g x2)) (f x) (beta) -- = \ x → (compose B C D h g) (f x) (fold compose) -- = compose A B D (compose B C D h g) f (fold compose)
docs.title: Solution to exercise 1.1

docs.text: This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1
docs.title: Solution to exercise 1.1

docs.text: Given functions \(f : A \to B\) and \(g : B \to C\) , define their composite \(g \circ f : A \to C\) . Show that we have \(h \circ (g \circ f) \equiv (h \circ g) \circ f\) .
docs.title: Problem statement

docs.text: #define compose ( A B C : U) ( g : B → C) ( f : A → B) : A → C := \ x → g (f x) Associativity is automatic (by refl ): #def compose_associativity ( A B C D : U) ( f : A -> B) ( g : B -> C) ( h : C -> D) : compose A C D h (compose A B C g f) = compose A B D (compose B C D h g) f := refl An explicit proof (not checked by rzk ): -- compose A C D h (compose A B C g f) -- = \ x → h ((compose A B C g f) x) (unfolding compose) -- = \ x → h ((\ x2 → g (f x2)) x) (unfolding compose) -- = \ x → h (g (f x)) (beta) -- = \ x → (\ x2 → h (g x2)) (f x) (beta) -- = \ x → (compose B C D h g) (f x) (fold compose) -- = compose A B D (compose B C D h g) f (fold compose)
docs.title: Solution

docs.text: Solution to exercise 1.2 ¶ This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1 Problem statement ¶ Derive the recursion principle for products \(\mathsf{rec}_{A \times B}\) using only the projections, and verify that the definitional equalities are valid. Do the same for \(\Sigma\) -types. Solution for products ¶ In this solution, we use prod , defined earlier in chapter 1.5 . Introducing constructor for values of prod type: #def pair ( A B : U) : A -> B -> prod A B := \ a b -> (a, b) Projections were also defined in chapter 1.5 ( pr₁ , pr₂ ). Type of the recursor on \(A \times B\) is \[ \mathsf{rec}_{A \times B}: \prod_{C:\mathcal{U}} (A \rightarrow B \rightarrow C) \rightarrow A \times B \rightarrow C \] Defining it through projections: #def prod-rec-via-projections ( A B : U) ( C : U) : ( g : A -> B -> C) -> ( p : prod A B) -> C := \ g p -> g (pr₁-via-rec A B p) (pr₂-via-rec A B p) Definitions of projections via recursion in the other direction were already provided in chapter 1.5 ( pr₁-via-rec , pr₂-via-rec ) Checking definitional equalities ¶ Recursion from projections: #def prod-rec-via-projections-works ( A B C : U) ( g : A -> B -> C) ( a : A) ( b : B) : prod-rec-via-projections A B C g (pair A B a b) = g a b := refl Warning TODO: Write down the explicit proof (in latex/rzk syntax) Projections from the recursion: #def pr₁-via-rec-works ( A B : U) ( a : A) ( b : B) : pr₁-via-rec A B (pair A B a b) = a := refl #def pr₂-from-rec-works ( A B : U) ( a : A) ( b : B) : pr₂-via-rec A B (pair A B a b) = b := refl Warning TODO: Write down the explicit proofs (in latex/rzk syntax) Solution for dependant pairs ¶ Sigma types are built-in. Also, pr₁-sigma , pr₂-sigma , rec-sigma , ind-sigma were already defined in chapter 1.6 . Defining recursion from pr₁-sigma and pr₂-sigma : #def rec-sigma-via-projections ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( C : U) : ( g : ( x : A) -> B x -> C) -> ( p : Sigma ( x : A), (B x)) -> C := \ g p -> g (pr₁-sigma A B p) (pr₂-sigma A B p) (Extra, not in the task) Other direction of definition (projecitons via recursion): #def pr₁-sigma-via-rec ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) : ( Sigma (x : A), (B x)) -> A := \ p -> rec-sigma A B A ( \ x y -> x) p For the second projection ( \(\mathsf{pr}_2\) ) we need the induction, since the output type depends on \(x : A\) : #def pr₂-sigma-via-rec ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) : ( p : Sigma ( x : A), (B x)) -> (B (pr₁-sigma-via-rec A B p)) := \ p -> ind-sigma A B ( \ p1 -> B (pr₁-sigma-via-rec A B p1)) ( \ x y -> y) p Checking the definitional equalities ¶ #def rec-sigma-via-projections-works ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( C : U) ( g : ( x : A) -> B x -> C) ( a : A) ( b : B a) : rec-sigma-via-projections A B C g (a, b) = g a b := refl #def pr₁-sigma-via-rec-works ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( a : A) ( b : B a) : pr₁-sigma-via-rec A B (a, b) = a := refl #def pr₂-sigma-via-rec-works ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( a : A) ( b : B a) : pr₂-sigma-via-rec A B (a, b) = b := refl Warning TODO: Write down the explicit proofs (in latex/rzk syntax)
docs.title: Solution to exercise 1.2

docs.text: This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1
docs.title: Solution to exercise 1.2

docs.text: Derive the recursion principle for products \(\mathsf{rec}_{A \times B}\) using only the projections, and verify that the definitional equalities are valid. Do the same for \(\Sigma\) -types.
docs.title: Problem statement

docs.text: In this solution, we use prod , defined earlier in chapter 1.5 . Introducing constructor for values of prod type: #def pair ( A B : U) : A -> B -> prod A B := \ a b -> (a, b) Projections were also defined in chapter 1.5 ( pr₁ , pr₂ ). Type of the recursor on \(A \times B\) is \[ \mathsf{rec}_{A \times B}: \prod_{C:\mathcal{U}} (A \rightarrow B \rightarrow C) \rightarrow A \times B \rightarrow C \] Defining it through projections: #def prod-rec-via-projections ( A B : U) ( C : U) : ( g : A -> B -> C) -> ( p : prod A B) -> C := \ g p -> g (pr₁-via-rec A B p) (pr₂-via-rec A B p) Definitions of projections via recursion in the other direction were already provided in chapter 1.5 ( pr₁-via-rec , pr₂-via-rec )
docs.title: Solution for products

docs.text: Recursion from projections: #def prod-rec-via-projections-works ( A B C : U) ( g : A -> B -> C) ( a : A) ( b : B) : prod-rec-via-projections A B C g (pair A B a b) = g a b := refl Warning TODO: Write down the explicit proof (in latex/rzk syntax) Projections from the recursion: #def pr₁-via-rec-works ( A B : U) ( a : A) ( b : B) : pr₁-via-rec A B (pair A B a b) = a := refl #def pr₂-from-rec-works ( A B : U) ( a : A) ( b : B) : pr₂-via-rec A B (pair A B a b) = b := refl Warning TODO: Write down the explicit proofs (in latex/rzk syntax)
docs.title: Checking definitional equalities

docs.text: Sigma types are built-in. Also, pr₁-sigma , pr₂-sigma , rec-sigma , ind-sigma were already defined in chapter 1.6 . Defining recursion from pr₁-sigma and pr₂-sigma : #def rec-sigma-via-projections ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( C : U) : ( g : ( x : A) -> B x -> C) -> ( p : Sigma ( x : A), (B x)) -> C := \ g p -> g (pr₁-sigma A B p) (pr₂-sigma A B p) (Extra, not in the task) Other direction of definition (projecitons via recursion): #def pr₁-sigma-via-rec ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) : ( Sigma (x : A), (B x)) -> A := \ p -> rec-sigma A B A ( \ x y -> x) p For the second projection ( \(\mathsf{pr}_2\) ) we need the induction, since the output type depends on \(x : A\) : #def pr₂-sigma-via-rec ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) : ( p : Sigma ( x : A), (B x)) -> (B (pr₁-sigma-via-rec A B p)) := \ p -> ind-sigma A B ( \ p1 -> B (pr₁-sigma-via-rec A B p1)) ( \ x y -> y) p
docs.title: Solution for dependant pairs

docs.text: #def rec-sigma-via-projections-works ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( C : U) ( g : ( x : A) -> B x -> C) ( a : A) ( b : B a) : rec-sigma-via-projections A B C g (a, b) = g a b := refl #def pr₁-sigma-via-rec-works ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( a : A) ( b : B a) : pr₁-sigma-via-rec A B (a, b) = a := refl #def pr₂-sigma-via-rec-works ( A : U) ( B : A -> U) ( a : A) ( b : B a) : pr₂-sigma-via-rec A B (a, b) = b := refl Warning TODO: Write down the explicit proofs (in latex/rzk syntax)
docs.title: Checking the definitional equalities

docs.text: Solution to exercise 1.3 ¶ This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1 Problem statement ¶ Derive the induction principle for products \(ind_{A \times B}\) , using only the projections and the propositional uniqueness principle \(uniq_{A \times B}\) . Verify that the definitional equalities are valid. Generalize \(uniq_{A \times B}\) to \(\Sigma\) -types, and do the same for \(\Sigma\) -types. (This requires concepts from Chapter 2.) Solution ¶
docs.title: Solution to exercise 1.3

docs.text: This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1
docs.title: Solution to exercise 1.3

docs.text: Solution to exercise 2.1 ¶ This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1 Problem statement ¶ Show that the three obvious proofs of Lemma 2.1.2 are pairwise equal. Lemma 2.1.2: (note we use \(\circ\) instead of square dot due to technical limitations) For every type \(A\) and every \(x, y, z : A\) there is a function \[ (x = y) \rightarrow (y = z) \rightarrow (x = z), \] written \(p \mapsto q \mapsto p \circ q\) , such that \(\text{refl}_x \circ \text{refl}_x \equiv \text{refl}_x\) for any \(x : A\) . We call \(p \circ q\) the concatenation or composite of \(p\) and \(q\) . Solution ¶
docs.title: Solution to exercise 2.1

docs.text: This is a literate Rzk file: #lang rzk-1
docs.title: Solution to exercise 2.1

docs.text: Show that the three obvious proofs of Lemma 2.1.2 are pairwise equal. Lemma 2.1.2: (note we use \(\circ\) instead of square dot due to technical limitations) For every type \(A\) and every \(x, y, z : A\) there is a function \[ (x = y) \rightarrow (y = z) \rightarrow (x = z), \] written \(p \mapsto q \mapsto p \circ q\) , such that \(\text{refl}_x \circ \text{refl}_x \equiv \text{refl}_x\) for any \(x : A\) . We call \(p \circ q\) the concatenation or composite of \(p\) and \(q\) .
